In this line, Paul McCartney calls upon the drug habits he picked up, more specifically cannabis. Paul is no stranger when it comes to drug usage though, as he was prosecuted and had to spend nine days in a Japanese jail for possession of marijuana.

Cannabis was introduced to The Beatles by Bob Dylan in a New York hotel room in 1964, and McCartney recalls getting “very high” and “giggling uncontrollably.”

His use of the drug became habitual, and it wasn’t long before he started getting into stronger drugs like LSD, which McCartney insisted did more good than harm, stating in an interview documented by Peter Brown and Steven Gaines in their book The Love You Make that:

It opened my eyes … and made me a better, more honest, more tolerant member of society.

Every single day of my life?

Well, not for the rest of his life. While it’s unclear when exactly he stopped, he told The Mirror in 2015 that he’d stopped smoking marijuana “a long time ago”:


“I don’t do it any more,” he explains. “Why? The truth is I don’t really want to set an example to my kids and grandkids. It’s now a parent thing.

“Back then I was just some guy around London having a ball, and the kids were little so I’d just try and keep it out of their faces.

“Instead of smoking a spliff I’ll now have a glass of red wine or a nice margarita. The last time I smoked was a long time ago.”
